image.altText: Adelaide woman Megan Macolino lights a candle in tribute to her stillborn baby.

props.synopsis: Every day six babies are, on average, stillborn across the country — and the rate has remained effectively unchanged for two decades. Evidence shows in many cases stillbirth is preventable, but experts are concerned that outdated attitudes and data delays are still holding back progress.

title.children: Baby Avery was stillborn at 35 weeks — he's part of a tragic trend that hasn't changed in 20 years

image.altText: Two red trains at a station

props.synopsis: The Rail, Tram, and Bus Union says workers will strike on the date of the first AFL Port Crows Showdown of the season, if pay demands from metro train staff are not met within the next two weeks.

title.children: Train drivers threaten 24-hour strike during first AFL Showdown of the season

props.synopsis: In Samoa, churches spend millions building cathedrals to connect communities to God. But as debts and poverty skyrocket, many are questioning the price tag.

title.children: These churches cost millions to build. In a cost of living crisis, many are questioning the price tags

image.altText: Mark Dreyfuss raising his hand and pointing.

props.synopsis: The nation's chief lawmaker has asked men to step up to stop women dying every week in a "crisis of male violence".

title.children: Dreyfus calls on men to 'step up' to stop one woman dying a week from domestic violence

image.altText: Two police officers updating the media

props.synopsis: The teenager's case was heard before a children's court where his lawyer argued he has a long history of mental health issues dating back to his childhood.

title.children: Court told teenager 'had long history' of mental health issues before allegedly stabbing bishop

image.altText: Three women smile for a camera while wearing designer clothing.

props.synopsis: There is a real-time example playing out on the world stage of how salaries are impacted by structures that were built for men decades before anyone thought to include women.

title.children: Caitlin Clark is this year's number one draft pick in the WNBA. Her salary has sparked outrage

image.altText: Snowtown accomplice Mark Ray Haydon in a car being escorted from court.

props.synopsis: Snowtown accomplice Mark Ray Haydon is being slowly reintroduced to the community, with the head of SA's Parole Board saying the "world has changed a lot" since he was taken into custody and he needs to learn how to use a mobile phone, access Centrelink and catch public transport.

title.children: 'The world has changed a lot': Snowtown accomplice's transition to life after 25 years in jail

image.altText: a generic image of a child standing by a window holding a doll. the light is shadowy and their identity isn't clear

props.synopsis: The death of a 10-year-old Indigenous boy raises serious questions about how well the system is coping with a surge in children in state care in Western Australia. WARNING: This story contains distressing content.

title.children: 'Unspeakable tragedy': Boy's suicide in state care prompts doubts about system's ability to cope

image.altText: An illustration showing a pink silhouette against a backdrop of Japanese imagery.

props.synopsis: A landmark racial discrimination case comes as the country grapples with questions about race, immigration and what it means to be Japanese.

title.children: 'Big elephant in the room': A lawsuit in Japan has put the spotlight on race

image.altText: Angry woman punching her screen

props.synopsis: Anger and fear dominate our world right now, but experts say those who are engineering these emotions are often doing so for the money.

title.children: Why are we all so angry right now? Many experts say we're being manipulated for profits

image.altText: A composite of photos, including a woman walking, Bluey, and Donald Trump

props.synopsis: Are you across this week's news headlines? Put yourself to the test.

title.children: Weekly news quiz: Bluey's longest episode, Australia's Olympic fashion, and Donald Trump's first trial

image.altText: An adult lies in a hospital bed.

props.synopsis: Elective surgery wait times are now the longest on record, according to the Australian Medical Association's Public Hospital Report Card.

title.children: Elective surgery wait times almost double in 20 years as patients wait longer in emergency

image.altText: Raina Cruise wearing sunglasses outdoors.

props.synopsis: Anti-vaccine protester Raina Cruise is found guilty of intentionally causing harm to a police officer after trial by judge alone.

title.children: Failed SA Senate candidate who tore hair from police officer found guilty of assault

image.altText: emergency services crowded on the street outside the shopping centre

props.synopsis: A leading neuropsychiatrist says there was a potential "systemic failure" by Queensland authorities when it came to treating and communicating about Joel Cauchi.

title.children: Specialist says there may have been 'systemic failures' between authorities over the treatment of Joel Cauchi

image.altText: Council members and staff sit around a round table. More more than 60 chairs arranged in three rows around it.

props.synopsis: The United States vetoes a widely backed UN resolution that would have paved the way for full United Nations membership for the state of Palestine.

title.children: US vetoes widely supported resolution backing full UN membership for Palestine

image.altText: Katy Gallagher, sitting with Jim Chalmers, holds the women's economic budget statement

props.synopsis: Treasurer Jim Chalmers's third budget will be his first not wholly dominated by inflation, which will share the stage with trouble in China and sluggish economic growth. What story will the government seek to tell?

title.children: For the first time this term, inflation may not dominate the budget. What will?

image.altText: Telstra chair John Mullen addresses the annual general meeting.

props.synopsis: Australia's stock market is down in early trade, after a mixed session on Wall Street overnight following another strong jobs report in the US. Meanwhile, Qantas says John Mullen will join its board as chairman-elect on Monday, three months earlier than expected. Follow live.

title.children: ASX down in early trade, John Mullen joins Qantas board next week as chairman-elect

image.altText: A sign of a waste facility with an arrow pointing towards public trailer waste.

props.synopsis: Daniel Gordon Bremner, who fatally bashed his housemate in Adelaide's east and placed his body in a wheelie bin, has been handed a life sentence.

title.children: Man who murdered frail housemate and placed his body in a wheelie bin handed life sentence

image.altText: Charlene O'Sullivan and Briony Goodsell

props.synopsis: It's been 15 years since Charlene O'Sullivan lost her daughter to a crocodile in a waterhole near Darwin. She's warning the Northern Territory government against culling.

title.children: Mother of girl taken by crocodile wants more education, not culling

image.altText: Indonesia volcano erupting.

props.synopsis: Indonesian rescuers race to evacuate thousands of people after a volcano erupted five times, forcing authorities to close a nearby airport and issue a tsunami warning.

title.children: Indonesia evacuating thousands after volcano erupts, as tsunami fear looms

image.altText: An abandoned vehicle stands in floodwater caused by heavy rain with the Burj Khalifa in Dubai

props.synopsis: The United Arab Emirates tries to wring itself out after the heaviest-recorded rainfall ever to hit the desert nation, with its main airport allowing more flights even as floodwater covered portions of major highways and communities.

title.children: United Arab Emirates struggles to recover after heaviest recorded rainfall ever

image.altText: Nicola Sturgeon, wearing red, waves at the media alongside her husband Peter Murrell.

props.synopsis: Murrell was re-arrested and questioned after he and Sturgeon were arrested last year in relation to the same investigation.

title.children: Ex-Scottish leader's husband charged with embezzling party funds

image.altText: Donald Trump sits in a suit, blue tie and white shirt looking sternly at the camera behind a desk

props.synopsis: Lawyers faced major challenges in trying to assemble a jury for one of the most high-profile cases in US history.

title.children: Twelve jurors selected for Donald Trump's 'hush money' New York trial after several dismissals

image.altText: Football players lie on the ground looking devastated at a loss.

props.synopsis: The Olyroos fail to score again as Indonesia causes an upset with a 1-0 victory that has almost shattered Australia's Olympic dream.

title.children: Australian men on brink of missing Olympics football after Olyroos suffer shock loss

image.altText: Wind turbines in the background, with golden paddock and sheep looking at the camera in the foreground

props.synopsis: The federal government plans to spend tens of billions of dollars building new green energy projects. An analyst is warning against "zombie projects" that go nowhere.

title.children: Mammoth federal green scheme risks 'zombie projects' that never get built, analyst warns

image.altText: A military base fenced with barbed wire

props.synopsis: Israel's defence force denies serious allegations of abuse and torture from several Gazan men who say they were detained without charge. WARNING: Readers might find some of the details in this story distressing.

title.children: 'I wish that no one sees what I've seen': Gazans make shocking claims about being imprisoned by the IDF

image.altText: A prop car in a forest

props.synopsis: In a beloved Melbourne wildlife reserve, Warner Brothers was given the green light to conjure up fantastical scenes straight from Harry Potter. But behind the scenes, the local council was warned this would risk banishing their own, real-world creatures.

title.children: A Harry Potter experience got a barrage of public backlash, but documents suggest it could've been avoided

image.altText: A young girl in a pink jacket with fake fangs screams at the camera

props.synopsis: Featuring the last filmed performance of Euphoria star Angus Cloud, Abigail’s cast puts in a lot more than they get out of the ambitious but bloated horror comedy.

title.children: Want to see a pre-teen in ballet flats kill some clueless criminals? Abigail may be for you

image.altText: Kids shoes on skateboard

props.synopsis: Seven months ago the Queensland government was warned that without an additional youth justice lawyer in Cairns, the number of youth detainees in the Cairns watch house would worsen. Advocates say that’s exactly what happened.

title.children: 'Inexplicable' that youth justice lawyer role in Cairns not approved, advocates say

image.altText: An unidentified person looks at a screen with property for rent on it.

props.synopsis: An error made by the owner meant Sarah became the sole tenant on the lease for a bargain price, but months later, people started showing up at her door.

title.children: When Sarah secured a family home near Brisbane for $115 a week, she had no idea of the nightmare that would follow

image.altText: A woman in a colourful shirt looking at the camera

props.synopsis: Upgrades to Broome Hospital's high dependency mental health unit were recommended by a coroner in 2021 after the death of an Aboriginal man, but the state government says it still "working through" what is required.

title.children: Expert flags 'incredible' mental health funding need in region with one of world's highest youth suicide rates

image.altText: Anthony Albanese at a press conference.

props.synopsis: Australia's multiculturalism is enduring unprecedented strains, with all the difficulties that brings for political and community leaders.

title.children: Ethnic tensions will complicate the Albanese government’s multicultural policy reform

image.altText: Kenya's Chief of Defence Francis Ogolla (left) wit Kenya's President William Ruto.

props.synopsis: General Francis Omondi Ogolla and other officials die while travelling in the North Rift region, where armed bandits and cattle rustlers are rampant.

title.children: Chopper crash kills Kenyan defence chief on visit to combat cattle rustlers

image.altText: Two children smiling run down the street in Bhutan.

props.synopsis: Bhutan is known for being one of the happiest countries in the world, but mental health professionals say its people are suffering in silence due to cultural traditions and societal expectations of positivity.

title.children: Bhutan is known for being a happy country, but mental health is a hidden problem
